questions.text: During fasting, the body employs various mechanisms to maintain blood glucose levels. Which of the following sequences correctly represents the order in which these mechanisms are activated to ensure blood glucose homeostasis in the fasting state?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glucose from diet > glycogenolysis > gluconeogenesis

 

Option A:

 

In the fasting state, after dietary glucose is depleted, the body first turns to glycogenolysis, the process of breaking down glycogen stored in the liver and muscle tissues into glucose, to maintain blood glucose levels. As fasting continues and glycogen stores become depleted, gluconeogenesis, the synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate substrates (such as lactate, glycerol, and amino acids), becomes the primary mechanism for maintaining blood glucose levels. This sequence ensures a continuous supply of glucose to vital organs, especially the brain, during periods of fasting.

 

 Explanation:

 

Option B. Glucose from diet > gluconeogenesis > glycogenolysis: This sequence is incorrect because glycogenolysis typically precedes gluconeogenesis in the fasting state as the body utilizes stored glycogen before synthesizing glucose from non-carbohydrate sources.

 

Option C. Glucose from diet > gluconeogenesis > proteolysis: While proteolysis (the breakdown of proteins) does contribute substrates for gluconeogenesis, it is not a direct mechanism for maintaining blood glucose levels but rather provides amino acids that can be used in gluconeogenesis.

 

Option D. Glucose from diet > lipolysis > gluconeogenesis: Lipolysis, the breakdown of triglycerides into free fatty acids and glycerol, does provide substrates for gluconeogenesis (specifically glycerol), but it primarily serves as a mechanism for providing energy through fatty acid oxidation rather than directly contributing to maintaining blood glucose levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During starvation:

 

  • Liver produces glucose by glycogenolysis and later by gluconeogenesis so that the obligatory requirements of the brain are met.
  • Liver also produces the ketone bodies, an alternate source of fuel. But the liver cannot use ketone bodies as its own fuel
  • In the fasting state
  • 2-2 1/2 hours – glucose from meals
  • Next 3 hours – from glycogenolysis
  • Later from gluconeogenesis (proteolysis & lipolysis)
  • Hyperglycemic hormones are secreted

 

Liver is the net producer of glucose in the fasting state

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 319-325.

questions.text: During a clinical review session, a medical instructor is discussing the various substrates that contribute to the production of glucose through gluconeogenesis. One of the students asks which substrates can be used by the liver to synthesize glucose. The instructor provides a list but includes one substrate that does not contribute to the net synthesis of glucose in gluconeogenesis. Which of the following does not serve as a substrate for net glucose production in gluconeogenesis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acetyl CoA

 

Option B:

 

Acetyl CoA cannot contribute to the net synthesis of glucose in gluconeogenesis. While it is a critical molecule in metabolism that enters the citric acid cycle, it does not serve as a gluconeogenic substrate because two carbons are lost as CO2 in the cycle, which precludes the net generation of glucose.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lactate: Lactate can be converted to pyruvate by lactate dehydrogenase and then to glucose via gluconeogenesis.

 

Option C. Pyruvate: Pyruvate is a key gluconeogenic substrate that can be carboxylated to oxaloacetate and eventually converted to glucose.

 

Option D. Alanine: Alanine can undergo transamination to form pyruvate, which can then enter the gluconeogenesis pathway to synthesize glucose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Substrates for Gluconeogenesis:

 

  • Glucogenic Amino Acid [Alanine is the major contributor]
  • Lactate
  • Glycerol
  • Propionyl CoA.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p185, 186.

choices.text: Level of fructose 1,6-biphosphate is lower than normal
Level of fructose 1,6-biphosphate is higher than normal

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with hypoglycaemia and metabolic acidosis. Laboratory investigations reveal a genetic disorder that causes the liver enzyme fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase to be more sensitive to inhibition by fructose 2,6-bisphosphate. This enzyme is a crucial regulatory point in gluconeogenesis. Based on this enzymatic defect, which of the following metabolic changes would be expected in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Level of fructose 1,6-biphosphate is higher than normal

 

  • The enzyme fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase plays a key regulatory role in gluconeogenesis.
  • It catalyzes the reaction:
    Fructose 1,6-bisphosphate → Fructose 6-phosphate + Pi.
  • This step is irreversible and crucial for glucose production in the liver, especially during fasting.
  • Fructose 2,6-bisphosphate is a potent allosteric inhibitor of fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase and an activator of phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1), pushing metabolism toward glycolysis and away from gluconeogenesis.

 

In this case:

  • The child’s fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase is overly sensitive to inhibition by fructose 2,6-bisphosphate.
  • This results in inhibited gluconeogenesis.
  • The blocked conversion of fructose 1,6-bisphosphate to fructose 6-phosphate causes a build-up of fructose 1,6-bisphosphate.

 

Thus, you expect:

  • ↓ Glucose production (hypoglycemia),
  • ↓ Gluconeogenesis,
  • ↑ Fructose 1,6-bisphosphate (due to the block).

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. Level of fructose 1,6-bisphosphate is lower than normal:
    Incorrect. Inhibition of the enzyme leads to accumulation, not depletion, of fructose 1,6-bisphosphate.
  • Option C. Increased glucose production:
    Incorrect. Gluconeogenesis is impaired, so glucose production decreases.
  • Option D. Increased gluconeogenesis:
    Incorrect. The mutation makes the enzyme more inhibited, so gluconeogenesis decreases.

 

Educational Objectives:

  • Fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase is a key regulatory enzyme in gluconeogenesis, inhibited by fructose 2,6-bisphosphate.
  • Its inhibition results in accumulation of fructose 1,6-bisphosphate and impaired glucose production.
  • This can cause fasting hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, and failure to thrive, especially in early childhood.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p169-170.

questions.text: Identifying the enzymes crucial for gluconeogenesis is essential for understanding metabolic pathways that contribute to glucose homeostasis. Which of the following options lists the key enzymes responsible for this process?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All the above.

 

Option D:

 

All the listed enzymes are pivotal in the gluconeogenesis pathway. Pyruvate carboxylase catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate in the mitochondria, which is a crucial first step. Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (PEPCK) then converts oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate, continuing the gluconeogenic process. Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase catalyzes the conversion of fructose-1,6-bisphosphate to fructose-6-phosphate, bypassing a key regulatory step of glycolysis and further advancing gluconeogenesis.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pyruvate carboxylase: Initiates gluconeogenesis by converting pyruvate to oxaloacetate.

 

Option B. Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase: Continues the pathway by converting oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate.

 

Option C. Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase: Crucial for bypassing a key glycolytic step in the reverse direction, converting fructose-1,6-bisphosphate to fructose-6-phosphate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Key Gluconeogenic Enzymes

 

  • Pyruvate carboxylase
  • Phosphoenol pyruvate carboxykinase
  • Fructose-1-6-bisphosphatase
  • Glucose-6-phosphatase

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p187.

choices.text: Carries amino group to the Liver
Alanine as a substrate for Gluconeogenesis during starvation

questions.text: In a remote clinic, a physician is treating a mountaineer for fatigue and muscle weakness after a prolonged trek. To understand the patient’s condition, the physician reviews metabolic processes that could be affected by long-term physical exertion and caloric deficit. Considering the body's adaptive mechanisms, which functions does the glucose-alanine cycle serve in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both A and B

 

Option C:

 

The glucose-alanine cycle is essential for transporting nitrogen in the form of amino groups to the liver and providing alanine as a substrate for gluconeogenesis. This cycle helps prevent muscle protein breakdown and supports glucose production during extended physical exertion, such as a long hike.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Carries amino group to the Liver: This is a correct function of the glucose-alanine cycle but does not fully capture the cycle's roles. It transports nitrogen to the liver, where it can be safely removed from the body.

 

Option B. Alanine as a substrate for Gluconeogenesis during starvation: This is another correct function, highlighting the cycle's role in supporting glucose production from non-carbohydrate sources during periods of starvation or intense physical activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uses of glucose-alanine (Cahill) cycle

 

  • Carries amino group to the Liver.
  • Alanine as a substrate for Gluconeogenesis during starvation.
  • Amino acid increased in blood during starvation is Alanine.

 

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e p:120.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is NOT directly involved in determining a cell's gluconeogenic capability?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pyruvate dehydrogenase

 

Option A:

 

Pyruvate dehydrogenase is an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, a key step in linking glycolysis with the citric acid cycle. This enzyme is not directly involved in gluconeogenesis, which is the process of synthesizing glucose from non-carbohydrate precursors. Instead, pyruvate dehydrogenase directs pyruvate towards energy production in the mitochondria and away from gluconeogenesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucose-6-phosphatase: This enzyme is crucial for the final step in gluconeogenesis, converting glucose-6-phosphate into free glucose, and is a determinant of a cell's ability to carry out gluconeogenesis.

 

Option C. Pyruvate carboxylase: Pyruvate carboxylase catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, an early step in gluconeogenesis, making it essential for this pathway.

 

Option D. Fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase: This enzyme catalyzes a key step in gluconeogenesis by converting fructose 1,6-bisphosphate back to fructose 6-phosphate, bypassing the glycolytic enzyme phosphofructokinase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gluconeogenesis is the process of synthesizing glucose or glycogen from non-carbohydrate precursors.
  • Gluconeogenic capacity is determined by the presence of key enzymes of Gluconeogenesis.
  • Pyruvate Dehydrogenase is not an enzyme of gluconeogenesis.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p188, 189.

questions.text: During a clinical rotation in endocrinology, a resident encounters a patient with a rare metabolic disorder that affects glucose production. Through discussions with the attending physician, the resident learns that the patient's condition involves a unique metabolic pathway that operates across two distinct cellular compartments, which is unusual compared to other pathways involved in glucose metabolism. Intrigued, the resident decides to research this further. Which metabolic pathway, relevant to the patient's condition, is known to occur across two different cellular compartments?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gluconeogenesis

 

Option A:

 

Gluconeogenesis is a metabolic process through which glucose is synthesized from non-carbohydrate precursors. This pathway is unique because it spans two cellular compartments: the cytoplasm and the mitochondria. In the liver, which is a key site for gluconeogenesis, certain steps of this pathway occur within the mitochondria, such as the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, while other steps take place in the cytoplasm, culminating in the production of glucose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycolysis: This process, the breakdown of glucose to pyruvate, occurs entirely within the cytoplasm and does not involve multiple compartments.

 

Option C. Glycogenesis: Glycogenesis, the process of glycogen synthesis from glucose, also occurs in the cytoplasm.

 

Option D. Glycogenolysis: The breakdown of glycogen to glucose-1-phosphate (and eventually glucose) in glycogenolysis is another process confined to the cytoplasm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gluconeogenesis takes place in both cytosol and mitochondria. The Mitochondrial step is Pyruvate Carboxylase reaction.

 

Pathways taking place in two compartments are –

 

  • Heme Synthesis
  • Urea Cycle
  • Gluconeogenesis

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p188, 189

questions.text: A pediatrician evaluates a child presenting with recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia, particularly noted during fasting periods. Further investigation reveals that the child has a metabolic condition impairing both glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for these metabolic disturbances in the child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glucose 6 Phosphatase

 

Option C:

 

Glucose 6-Phosphatase is a key enzyme in the final step of both glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis, converting glucose 6-phosphate into free glucose for release into the bloodstream. A deficiency in this enzyme would impair the ability to maintain normal blood glucose levels by inhibiting the final steps of both pathways, leading to hypoglycemia, especially during periods of fasting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fructokinase: This enzyme is involved in fructose metabolism. A deficiency would lead to fructosemia or fructosuria but not directly to impaired glycogenolysis or gluconeogenesis.

 

Option B. Glucokinase: Glucokinase functions in the liver to phosphorylate glucose to glucose 6-phosphate, initiating glycogen synthesis and glycolysis. A deficiency would affect glucose sensing and storage but is not directly involved in the final steps of glycogenolysis or gluconeogenesis.

 

Option D. Transketolase: This enzyme is part of the pentose phosphate pathway, not directly involved in glycogenolysis or gluconeogenesis. Its deficiency would not lead to the described clinical presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose 6-phosphatase deficiency is a cause of impaired glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis, leading to hypoglycemia

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p177.

choices.text: Occur in both muscle and liver
Excess of acetyl CoA stimulate it
Carbon skeleton of amino acid is involved

questions.text: Identify which of the following statements about gluconeogenesis is incorrect:
questions.solution:
Ans. B)  Occur in both muscle and liver

 

Option B:

 

Gluconeogenesis is a metabolic pathway that results in the generation of glucose from certain non-carbohydrate carbon substrates. While it predominantly occurs in the liver, it can also occur in the kidneys to a lesser extent, especially during prolonged fasting. However, it does not take place in muscle tissues because muscles lack the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase, which is necessary for the final step of gluconeogenesis.

 

other options:

 

Option A. It helps prevent hypoglycemia during prolonged fasting: This statement is true. Gluconeogenesis is crucial for maintaining blood glucose levels during fasting.

 

Option C. It is stimulated by an excess of acetyl CoA: This is true to some extent. Acetyl CoA can activate pyruvate carboxylase, an enzyme involved in the first step of gluconeogenesis.

 

Option D. It involves the carbon skeletons of amino acids: This is true. Amino acids can be deaminated and their carbon skeletons converted into gluconeogenic intermediates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gluconeogenesis occur in liver and kidney not in the muscle
  • Gluconeogenesis prevents hypoglycaemia in prolonged fasting
  • Excess Acetyl CoA is an allosteric activator of Pyruvate Carboxylase, a key enzyme of Gluconeogenesis
  • Carbon skeletons of gluconeogenic amino acids are involved in gluconeogenesis.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p187
